Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: My phone buzzed with a new email from Sarah, my teammate. The subject line read, “FYI: Updated Project Timeline.” She’d even written, “No action needed right now, just keeping you in the loop.” Still, as a colleague, I knew the unspoken rule: respond soon, show you’re engaged, be a team player. But my headset was already pinching my ear, and the clock on my screen glared 4:15 PM—the last day of the quarter. As a telemarketer, I was three sales short of my target, and the whole team’s bonus hung in the balance. Management’s emails had been relentless: “Every call counts. Don’t let up.” My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between dashing off a quick reply to Sarah and dialing the next number on my list. I could almost hear my manager’s voice in one ear, my colleague’s expectations in the other. The pressure built in my chest, and I stared at the blinking cursor, caught between being a reliable teammate and a relentless seller, knowing I couldn’t be both at once.
